Haze over the Gulf of Mexico.title: Haze over the Gulf of Mexico
Haze over the Gulf of Mexico.caption_short: This true-color image from April 12, 2009, shows multiple smoke plumes blowing northward off the Yucatán Peninsula and over the Gulf of Mexico.

Fires in Texas and Oklahoma.title: Fires in Texas and Oklahoma
Fires in Texas and Oklahoma.caption_short: A line of fires stretched across the plains west of Dallas-Forth Worth on April 9, 2009, and strong winds were driving smoke plumes from the fires toward the cities.

Etosha Pan, Namibia.title: Etosha Pan, Namibia
Etosha Pan, Namibia.caption_short: Flood water in the Oshigambo River, resulting from heavy rains in Angola, appears as a gray stream entering the northwest corner of Namibia’s Etosha Pan in this astronaut photo from March 26, 2009.

Elk Hills Oil Field, California.title: Elk Hills Oil Field, California
Elk Hills Oil Field, California.caption_short: Among the most productive oil fields in the United States, Elk Hills Oil Field in California presents a complicated surface in this image from March 7, 2009.

Dust Storm in Northeastern Arizona.title: Dust Storm in Northeastern Arizona
Dust Storm in Northeastern Arizona.caption_short: A MODIS image shows a dust storm blowing through northeastern Arizona in early April 2009. Clear skies allow a view of numerous source points for the storm.

Plume from Mount Redoubt.title: Plume from Mount Redoubt
Plume from Mount Redoubt.caption_short: A GOES image shows a plume from Mount Redoubt rising above the surrounding clouds before dissipating and spreading northward on March 26, 2009.

Haze over the Sea of Japan.title: Haze over the Sea of Japan
Haze over the Sea of Japan.caption_short: A thick swath of smog and/or dust swept over the Sea of Japan on March 11, 2008. A significant portion of the plume could result from dust remaining from an earlier storm.

Amount of Old Ice in Arctic Hits Record.title: Amount of Old Ice in Arctic Hits Record Low in February 2009
Amount of Old Ice in Arctic Hits Record.caption_short: This pair of maps shows how the sea ice covering the Arctic at winter maximum in 2009 is younger than it was in the past.

Steam Plume from Mount Redoubt.title: Steam Plume from Mount Redoubt
Steam Plume from Mount Redoubt.caption_short: A MODIS image of Redoubt from April 7, 2009, shows a nearly white volcanic plume, likely consisting primarily of water vapor.

Lahars Near the Drift River Oil Terminal.title: Lahars Near the Drift River Oil Terminal
Lahars Near the Drift River Oil Terminal.caption_short: Lahars from Alaska’s Mt. Redoubt Volcano pass close to the Drift River Oil Terminal in an image acquired on April 4, 2009.

Haze over the Sea of Azov.title: Haze over the Sea of Azov
Haze over the Sea of Azov.caption_short: MODIS shows a narrow east-west band of haze over and west of the Sea of Azov on April 7, 2009.

Ashfalls from Redoubt Volcano.title: Ashfalls from Redoubt Volcano
Ashfalls from Redoubt Volcano.caption_short: Activity at Mount Redoubt caused rapid changes on the nearby landscape in early April 2009.

Earthquake in Central Italy.title: Earthquake in Central Italy
Earthquake in Central Italy.caption_short: This image of central Italy shows the rugged topography in the vicinity of L’Aquila, where a magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck on April 6, 2009.

Tropical Storm Jade.title: Tropical Storm Jade
Tropical Storm Jade.caption_short: The center of Tropical Storm Jade is nearly over the eastern Madagascar shore in this photo-like image from April 6, 2009.

Fires in Southern Mexico and Central Ame.title: Fires in Southern Mexico and Central America
Fires in Southern Mexico and Central Ame.caption_short: Fires across southern Mexico and northern Central America spread smoke across the Gulf of Mexico’s Campeche Bay on April 4, 2009.

Atafu Atoll, Tokelau.title: Atafu Atoll, Tokelau
Atafu Atoll, Tokelau.caption_short: The ring shape is the result of coral reefs building up around a former volcanic island in the South Pacific.

Rospuda Valley, Poland.title: Rospuda Valley, Poland
Rospuda Valley, Poland.caption_short: Rospuda Valley is home to one of Europe’s last pristine wetlands. A Landsat 7 image shows the patchwork of peat bog and agricultural fields around Rospuda Valley.

The Red River Flood Plain.title: The Red River Flood Plain
The Red River Flood Plain.caption_short: Repeated flooding in the Red River basin is mostly due to its topographic setting and geologic history, as illustrated in this image of the ground elevation near Fargo, North Dakota.

Great Blue Hole, Belize.title: Great Blue Hole, Belize
Great Blue Hole, Belize.caption_short: A vertical cave in Belize’s Lighthouse Reef Atoll comprises a popular diving site known as the Great Blue Hole. The Advanced Land Imager on NASA’s Earth Observing-1 satellite captured an image of the Great Blue Hole and Lighthouse Reef in March 2009.

Flooding around Ondangwa, Namibia.title: Flooding around Ondangwa, Namibia
Flooding around Ondangwa, Namibia.caption_short: The northern Namibian city of Ondangwa seems to be built on a sponge in these images, which show flooding around the city on March 28, 2009.

Flooding around Oshakati, Namibia.title: Flooding around Oshakati, Namibia
Flooding around Oshakati, Namibia.caption_short: This pair of images from the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) on NASA’ Terra satellite shows wide-spread flooding in Oshakati, Namibia, on March 28, 2009.

Flooding on the Cuvelai River, Namibia.title: Flooding on the Cuvelai River, Namibia
Flooding on the Cuvelai River, Namibia.caption_short: Wide channels brimming with water transform the Cuvelai basin in this image of flooding, taken on March 28, 2009.

Mount Redoubt Stirs.title: Mount Redoubt Stirs
Mount Redoubt Stirs.caption_short: In contrast to the explosive eruptions of the previous week, ash emissions from Mount Redoubt became more frequent but confined to lower altitudes on March 30, 2009. The commercial satellite GeoEye-1 captured a high-resolution view of the volcano the same day.

Fires in East Gippsland, Victoria.title: Fires in East Gippsland, Victoria
Fires in East Gippsland, Victoria.caption_short: Several bushfires were burning in state and national parks in the eastern corner of Victoria on March 31, 2009, spreading smoke across a large area of southern Victoria.

Mt. Redoubt Volcano, Alaska.title: Mt. Redoubt Volcano, Alaska
Mt. Redoubt Volcano, Alaska.caption_short: The glacier-covered Redoubt Volcano is one of many that line Alaska’s southern shores. In late January 2009, the volcano started to rumble once again.

Spring Snow Brings Moisture to Colorado.title: Spring Snow Brings Moisture to Colorado Front Range
Spring Snow Brings Moisture to Colorado.caption_short: A pair of images from the MODIS sensor on NASA’s Terra satellite shows Denver and the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains before and after a spring snow storm blanketed the area in white on March 27, 2009.

Betsiboka River Floods, Madagascar&mdash.title: Betsiboka River Floods, Madagascar—January 2009
Betsiboka River Floods, Madagascar&mdash.caption_short: Two storms—Tropical Storm Eric and Cyclone Fanele—swept across eastern Madagascar within days of each other in January 2009. Rain from the storms swelled the Betsiboka River with floodwater.

Piton de la Fournaise.title: Piton de la Fournaise
Piton de la Fournaise.caption_short: Piton de la Fournaise erupts almost every year, primarily from the lava shield named Dolomieu. A January 2009 image of this volcano shows signs of previous volcanic activity.

Submarine Eruption in the Tonga Islands.title: Submarine Eruption in the Tonga Islands
Submarine Eruption in the Tonga Islands.caption_short: On March 18, 2009, the Tonga Islands submarine eruption appeared as a blue-green blur under the water. A pumice raft floated on the nearby ocean surface.

Spring Snow over Denver, Colorado.title: Spring Snow over Denver, Colorado
Spring Snow over Denver, Colorado.caption_short: The even grid of Denver’s streets is visible beneath the snow laid down by a storm on March 26, 2009.

Severe Thunderstorms over Mississippi.title: Severe Thunderstorms over Mississippi
Severe Thunderstorms over Mississippi.caption_short: These images show the heavy rainfall brought by severe thunderstorms over the southeastern United States on March 26, 2009.

Cyclone Izilda.title: Cyclone Izilda
Cyclone Izilda.caption_short: Never a strong storm, Cyclone Izilda was near its peak strength when this photo-like image was taken.

The World Archipelago, Persian Gulf.title: The World Archipelago, Persian Gulf
The World Archipelago, Persian Gulf.caption_short: This pair of images from the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) on NASA’s Terra satellite show the development of the archipelago known as “The World.” The group of manmade islands is arranged to resemble a map of the world.

Dust Plumes over Central Asia.title: Dust Plumes over Central Asia
Dust Plumes over Central Asia.caption_short: Afghanistan and Turkmenistan exchanged dust in late March 2009 as winds blew different plumes in different directions.

Unusual Wave Clouds over the Aral Sea.title: Unusual Wave Clouds over the Aral Sea
Unusual Wave Clouds over the Aral Sea.caption_short: Distinctive lines of clouds that mirror the shape of the shore hang over the Aral Sea in this photo-like image.

Dust East and West of the Red Sea.title: Dust East and West of the Red Sea
Dust East and West of the Red Sea.caption_short: Dust blew over the Arabian Peninsula and the Red Sea on March 24, 2009.

Ashfall from Redoubt Volcano.title: Ashfall from Redoubt Volcano
Ashfall from Redoubt Volcano.caption_short: Mount Redoubt sent a column of ash some 19 kilometers skyward. On March 23, 2009, ash was visible on the snowy land surface north of the volcano.

Ash Plumes from Redoubt Volcano.title: Ash Plumes from Redoubt Volcano
Ash Plumes from Redoubt Volcano.caption_short: Thermal infrared images reveal ash plumes from Alaska’s Mt. Redoubt Volcano on March 23, 2009.

Summit of Popocatepetl Volcano, Mexico.title: Summit of Popocatepetl Volcano, Mexico
Summit of Popocatepetl Volcano, Mexico.caption_short: This detailed astronaut photograph shows the summit crater of Mexico’s Popocatepetl Volcano on February 7, 2009.

Kings Canyon National Park.title: Kings Canyon National Park
Kings Canyon National Park.caption_short: Kings Canyon and Sequoia National Parks contain a substantial portion of the Sierra Nevada and some 3,000 ponds and lakes.

Sea Ice Extent as the Equinox Approaches.title: Sea Ice Extent as the Equinox Approaches
Sea Ice Extent as the Equinox Approaches.caption_short: Arctic sea ice reaches its maximum extent in mid-March, around the time of the Vernal Equinox. After the Equinox, sunlight shines at the North Pole constantly until fall, and the sea ice will gradually decline.

Cyclone Ilsa.title: Cyclone Ilsa
Cyclone Ilsa.caption_short: This image shows Category 3-strength Tropical Cyclone Ilsa on March 19, 2009.

Sunspots at Solar Maximum and Minimum.title: Sunspots at Solar Maximum and Minimum
Sunspots at Solar Maximum and Minimum.caption_short: Our Sun experienced fewer sunspots in 2008 than it had since the 1957 launch of Sputnik. As of Sun-Earth Day on March 20, 2009, the Sun was continuing its quiet pattern.

Cathedral Fire, Wilson&rsquo;s Promontor.title: Cathedral Fire, Wilson’s Promontory, Victoria
Cathedral Fire, Wilson&rsquo;s Promontor.caption_short: The Cathedral Fire in Wilson’s Promontory National Park left a large burn scar across the landscape. This image of the burned area was captured on March 14, 2009, the day the fire was officially declared contained.

Gobi Desert Dust.title: Gobi Desert Dust
Gobi Desert Dust.caption_short: In this photo-like image of the Gobi Desert from March 14, 2009, two streams of dust appear, the northern plume skirting the Mongolian border.

Bushfires in Southeast Australia.title: Bushfires in Southeast Australia
Bushfires in Southeast Australia.caption_short: This image from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Aqua satellite shows multiple large fires (outlined in red) burning in Victoria, Australia, on February 7.

Ocean Life in the Ross Sea.title: Ocean Life in the Ross Sea
Ocean Life in the Ross Sea.caption_short: MODIS captured two views of the Ross Sea in December 2005. Although the true-color view showed a nearly uniform ocean color, the view of chlorophyll concentration revealed a wide range of productivity.

Dust Storm over Argentina.title: Dust Storm over Argentina
Dust Storm over Argentina.caption_short: Onshore winds sent dust plumes flying inland over Argentina near the city of Viedma in mid-March 2009.

Lake Badwater, Death Valley.title: Lake Badwater, Death Valley
Lake Badwater, Death Valley.caption_short: This pair of images from NASA’s Landsat 5 satellite documents the short history of Death Valley’s Lake Badwater: formed in February 2005 and long gone by February 2007.

Mawson Peak, Heard Island.title: Mawson Peak, Heard Island
Mawson Peak, Heard Island.caption_short: This detailed astronaut photograph shows Big Ben Volcano on Heard Island, north of Antarctica, including Mawson Peak and the Gotley and Lied Glaciers.

El Paso, Texas.title: El Paso, Texas
El Paso, Texas.caption_short: Though governed by separate countries, the cities of El Paso, Texas, and Juarez, Mexico, merge into an apparently seamless metropolis in this satellite image, but vegetation is confined mostly to the United States' side of the border.

Forest Fires in Nepal.title: Forest Fires in Nepal
Forest Fires in Nepal.caption_short: On March 12, 2009, the MODIS instrument on NASA’s Aqua satellite caught a glimpse of a relatively rare event: largeâ€“scale forest fires in the Himalaya Mountains of Nepal.

Ice on Lake Superior.title: Ice on Lake Superior
Ice on Lake Superior.caption_short: A relatively rare blanket of ice rested on the surface of Lake Superior in early March 2009.

Dust Plumes over Central Africa.title: Dust Plumes over Central Africa
Dust Plumes over Central Africa.caption_short: Multiple plumes of dust blew over the countries that fringe Lake Chad on February 11, 2009.

Ashfall from Shiveluch Volcano, Kamchatk.title: Ashfall from Shiveluch Volcano, Kamchatka
Ashfall from Shiveluch Volcano, Kamchatk.caption_short: When the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Aqua satellite captured this image of Shiveluch Volcano on March 11, an ash trail was visible on the snowy landscape of the Kamchatka Peninsula.

Ship Tracks South of Alaska.title: Ship Tracks South of Alaska
Ship Tracks South of Alaska.caption_short: On March 4, 2009, the skies over the northeast Pacific Ocean were streaked with clouds that form around the particles in ship exhaust.

Ice on Saginaw Bay, Lake Huron.title: Ice on Saginaw Bay, Lake Huron
Ice on Saginaw Bay, Lake Huron.caption_short: Lakeshore residents of Linwood, Michigan, were invaded by mountains of ice on the evening of March 8, 2009, as winds drove ice ashore from Saginaw Bay in Lake Huron. These images show the break-up of ice on the bay.

Dust Storm over the Arabian Peninsula.title: Dust Storm over the Arabian Peninsula
Dust Storm over the Arabian Peninsula.caption_short: Dust plumes swept across the Arabian Peninsula in early March 2009, stretching from the Red Sea to the Persian Gulf and beyond.

Haze over the Ethiopia-Sudan Border.title: Haze over the Ethiopia-Sudan Border
Haze over the Ethiopia-Sudan Border.caption_short: Haze that was probably a combination of dust and smoke lined the border between Sudan and Ethiopia in early March 2009.

Tropical Cyclone Hamish.title: Tropical Cyclone Hamish
Tropical Cyclone Hamish.caption_short: Powerful Tropical Cyclone Hamish formed in the Coral Sea off northeast Australia on March 5, 2009, and intensified into a strong Category 4 storm as it moved southeast along the Queensland coast.

Dust Plumes over the Taklimakan Desert.title: Dust Plumes over the Taklimakan Desert
Dust Plumes over the Taklimakan Desert.caption_short: A combination of dust and clouds swirled over the Taklimakan Desert in early March 2009.

Fires in Burma, Thailand, and Laos.title: Fires in Burma, Thailand, and Laos
Fires in Burma, Thailand, and Laos.caption_short: Thick smoke hung over eastern Burma (Myanmar), Thailand, and Laos on March 9, 2009, when the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Aqua satellite passed over head and captured this image. Scores of active fires (red outlines) were detected.

Fires in Eastern India and Northwest Bur.title: Fires in Eastern India and Northwest Burma (Myanmar)
Fires in Eastern India and Northwest Bur.caption_short: Scores of active fires were burning in eastern India and the mountainous provinces of northwest Burma (Myanmar) on March 9, 2009, when the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Aqua satellite passed overhead and captured this photo-like image.

Minchinmavida and Chaiten Volcanoes, Chi.title: Minchinmavida and Chaiten Volcanoes, Chile
Minchinmavida and Chaiten Volcanoes, Chi.caption_short: This astronaut photograph highlights two volcanoes located near the southern boundary of the Nazca–South America subduction zone in southern Chile. Dominating the scene is the massive Minchinmávida Volcano at image center. At bottom center is its smaller, but currently active, neighbor Chaitén.

Hells Canyon National Recreation Area.title: Hells Canyon National Recreation Area
Hells Canyon National Recreation Area.caption_short: This natural-color image of Hells Canyon was captured by NASA’s Landsat-7 satellite on September 19, 2002. The image shows the northern part of the canyon, where the Imnaha River joins the Snake River.

Utah Dust Storm.title: Utah Dust Storm
Utah Dust Storm.caption_short: This image of a dust storm in Utah was captured by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Terra satellite on March 4, 2009.

Snow Cover, December 2008 and February 2.title: Snow Cover, December 2008 and February 2009
Snow Cover, December 2008 and February 2.caption_short: This pair of maps shows average percent snow cover in December 2008 and February 2009, the first and last months of meteorological winter in the Northern Hemisphere.

Dust off the United Arab Emirates.title: Dust off the United Arab Emirates
Dust off the United Arab Emirates.caption_short: Heat and dust storms plagued the United Arab Emirates at the end of February 2009.

Floods in East Java, Indonesia.title: Floods in East Java, Indonesia
Floods in East Java, Indonesia.caption_short: Days of heavy rain sent the Solo River in East Java over its banks, inundating thousands of homes.

Snow Along the East Coast.title: Snow Along the East Coast
Snow Along the East Coast.caption_short: Snow blanketed the East Coast in this image from March 3, 2009.

Auckland, New Zealand.title: Auckland, New Zealand
Auckland, New Zealand.caption_short: This natural-color (photo-like) image of Auckland was acquired on August 27, 2002, by NASA’s Landsat 7 satellite.  The most densely developed areas appear white and gray, while suburban areas appear grayish green—a mixture of houses, streets, and lawns. The city spreads out across various peninsulas surrounding Tamaki Strait and other bays and inlets.

Dust South of the Sahel.title: Dust South of the Sahel
Dust South of the Sahel.caption_short: A combination of dust and clouds hovered over Africa south of the Sahel at the beginning of March 2009.

Kerguelen Kelp Beds, Southern Indian Oce.title: Kerguelen Kelp Beds, Southern Indian Ocean
Kerguelen Kelp Beds, Southern Indian Oce.caption_short: This astronaut photo from January 6, 2009, shows giant kelp beds in the waters surrounding Mac Murdo and Howe Islands—2 of the 300 islands that make up the Kerguélen Archipelago in the southern Indian Ocean.

25 Years of Growth in Las Vegas.title: 25 Years of Growth in Las Vegas
25 Years of Growth in Las Vegas.caption_short: Las Vegas experienced rapid growth between 1984 and 2009, and the growth was recorded by NASA’s long-lived Landsat 5 satellite.

Drought in Southern South America.title: Drought in Southern South America
Drought in Southern South America.caption_short: This vegetation index image represents the impact of one of the worst droughts in southern South America in decades.

Redoubt Volcano Summit.title: Redoubt Volcano Summit
Redoubt Volcano Summit.caption_short: This satellite image shows volcanic features on the summit of Redoubt Volcano, Alaska. Scientists believe an eruption at the volcano is likely in the coming weeks and months.

Northern Hokkaido, Japan.title: Northern Hokkaido, Japan
Northern Hokkaido, Japan.caption_short: Sea ice formed delicate swirls of blue and white in the Sea of Okhotsk in February 2009.

Clouds Streets and von Karman Vortices,.title: Clouds Streets and von Karman Vortices, Greenland Sea
Clouds Streets and von Karman Vortices,.caption_short: Cloud streets and von Karman vortices decorated the skies over the Greenland Sea on February 24, 2009.

Continuing Effects of Chaiten Volcano.title: Continuing Effects of Chaiten Volcano
Continuing Effects of Chaiten Volcano.caption_short: Days after a large-scale eruption from Chile's Chaiten Volcano on February 19, 2009, volcanic ash lingered on the Patagonian landscape.

Melting on the Greenland Ice Cap, 2008.title: Melting on the Greenland Ice Cap, 2008
Melting on the Greenland Ice Cap, 2008.caption_short: The northern fringes of Greenland's ice sheet saw extreme melting in 2008, according to NASA scientist Marco Tedesco and his colleagues.

Drought in Argentina.title: Drought in Argentina
Drought in Argentina.caption_short: This pair of natural-color (photo-like) images from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Terra satellite contrasts 2009 conditions in southern Buenos Aires province with the conditions in 2008, a more normal year.

Dust over the Middle East.title: Dust over the Middle East
Dust over the Middle East.caption_short: Dust blew through Syria, Iraq, and Saudi Arabia in late February 2009.

All-American Canal.title: All-American Canal
All-American Canal.caption_short: The largest irrigation canal in the world and a key landmark along the U.S.-Mexico border shows up in this astronaut photograph. This image captures about 15 kilometers (9.3 miles) of the important infrastructure corridor just west of Yuma, Arizona.

Redwood National Park.title: Redwood National Park
Redwood National Park.caption_short: State parks had already been established in the region when the U.S. Congress established northern California’s Redwood National Park in 1968.

Eruption of Chaiten Volcano.title: Eruption of Chaiten Volcano
Eruption of Chaiten Volcano.caption_short: A new eruption of the Chaitén Volcano forced authorities to evacuate residents who had returned to the nearby town of the same name. Ash emissions from the eruption spread across Patagonia to the Argentine east coast.

Volcanic Activity on Mt. Asama, Japan.title: Volcanic Activity on Mt. Asama, Japan
Volcanic Activity on Mt. Asama, Japan.caption_short: Volcanic ash covers the upper slopes of Mount Asama, the most active volcano on the island of Honshu, Japan

The Bahamas.title: The Bahamas
The Bahamas.caption_short: East of southern Florida, large swaths of ocean water glow peacock blue, thanks to their shallow depths. Near Florida and Cuba, the underwater terrain is hilly, and the crests of many of these hills comprise the islands of the Bahamas.

Volcanic Activity on Mt. Erebus.title: Volcanic Activity on Mt. Erebus
Volcanic Activity on Mt. Erebus.caption_short: Antarctica’s Mount Erebus may be covered with glaciers, but they do little to cool the volcano’s molten core. A lava lake is visible at the volcano’s summit.

Bushfires around Marysville, Victoria.title: Bushfires around Marysville, Victoria
Bushfires around Marysville, Victoria.caption_short: This false-color image shows the Killmore East-Murrundindi Complex North Fire in the Cathedral Range Mountains of Victoria, Australia, on February 17, 2009.

Killmore East-Murrindindi Complex South.title: Killmore East-Murrindindi Complex South Fire, Victoria
Killmore East-Murrindindi Complex South.caption_short: Among the areas devastated by bushfires in Victoria, Australia, in early February 2009 were Kinglake National Park and the surrounding rural and agricultural areas.

Volcanic Activity on Mt. Asama.title: Volcanic Activity on Mt. Asama
Volcanic Activity on Mt. Asama.caption_short: Asama Volcano on the Japanese island of Honshu showed signs of unrest, including ash plumes and increased seismic activity, starting in late January 2009.

Bushfires around Melbourne, Australia.title: Bushfires around Melbourne, Australia
Bushfires around Melbourne, Australia.caption_short: This image of the area northeast of Melbourne was captured by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Terra satellite on February 16.

Bushfire in Wilson&rsquo;s Promontory Na.title: Bushfire in Wilson’s Promontory National Park
Bushfire in Wilson&rsquo;s Promontory Na.caption_short: This image of a fire in Victoria’s Wilson’s Promontory National Park was captured by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Terra satellite on February 16.

Tetiaroa Island, French Polynesia.title: Tetiaroa Island, French Polynesia
Tetiaroa Island, French Polynesia.caption_short: This astronaut photograph shows Tetiaroa Island, part of the Society Islands archipelago in the southern Pacific Ocean. Tetiaroa is an atoll comprised of thirteen small islets.

Predicting Rift Valley Fever.title: Predicting Rift Valley Fever
Predicting Rift Valley Fever.caption_short: Using satellite data, scientists predicted an outbreak of Rift Valley fever in East Africa months before the first human cases were reported. The early prediction gave governments time to mitigate the spread of the disease.

Wolf Volcano, Galapagos Islands.title: Wolf Volcano, Galapagos Islands
Wolf Volcano, Galapagos Islands.caption_short: Volcan Wolf’s first historical eruption was recorded in 1797, and nine more documented eruptions followed over the next two centuries.

Gettysburg National Military Park.title: Gettysburg National Military Park
Gettysburg National Military Park.caption_short: Soldiers’ National Cemetery, where U.S. President Abraham Lincoln delivered the “Gettysburg Address” in November 1863, appears in this Ikonos satellite image from June 25, 2003.

Cyclone Gael.title: Cyclone Gael
Cyclone Gael.caption_short: Tropical Cyclone Gael hovered northeast of Mauritius in the southern Indian Ocean on February 4, 2009.

Santa Barbara, California.title: Santa Barbara, California
Santa Barbara, California.caption_short: This detailed astronaut photograph highlights the Santa Barbara, California, metropolitan area, sometimes called the “American Riviera.”

Aquaculture and Salt Production near Bo.title: Aquaculture and Salt Production near Bo Hai, China
Aquaculture and Salt Production near Bo.caption_short: China’s Bo Hai coast is one example of the rapid expansion of aquaculture in the late twentieth century.

Stratosphere Influences Winter Weather.title: Stratosphere Influences Winter Weather
Stratosphere Influences Winter Weather.caption_short: Winter turned fierce in the opening weeks of 2009, and part of the reason for the cold snaps and winter storms came from  big changes in the atmosphere about 20 kilometers above the Earth.

Wind Speeds off the Coast of Southern Br.title: Wind Speeds off the Coast of Southern Brazil
Wind Speeds off the Coast of Southern Br.caption_short: This image shows a satellite-based estimate of offshore wind power potential in the Atlantic Ocean southeast of Brazil.

Dust Plumes over the Gulf of Oman.title: Dust Plumes over the Gulf of Oman
Dust Plumes over the Gulf of Oman.caption_short: Multiple dust plumes blew southward over the Gulf of Oman in early February 2009.

Exceptional Australian Heat Wave.title: Exceptional Australian Heat Wave
Exceptional Australian Heat Wave.caption_short: A broad swath of above-average land surface temperatures stretched across southern Australia in late January and early February 2009.

Cyclone Ellie.title: Cyclone Ellie
Cyclone Ellie.caption_short: This image shows rainfall totals for January 27 through February 3, 2009, for northeastern Australia and the surrounding region, where Cyclone Ellie made landfall on February 2.

Snowy England.title: Snowy England
Snowy England.caption_short: Snow stretches from the English Channel north under a bank of clouds near the Scottish border in this photo-like image of England, taken on February 4, 2009.

November 2008 Alu/Dalaffilla Fissure Eru.title: November 2008 Alu/Dalaffilla Fissure Eruption
November 2008 Alu/Dalaffilla Fissure Eru.caption_short: The landscape of the Afar region in northern Ethiopia results from tectonic forces working deep below the surface, both splitting Africa apart and producing volcanic eruptions. Lava from a November 2008 eruption at the Erta Ale Range remained visible months later.

Snowy London.title: Snowy London
Snowy London.caption_short: The first days of February 2009 brought a fierce winter storm to countries throughout Western Europe. England received its heaviest snowfall in 18 years. This image shows snow in and around London.

Oil Seeps in the Gulf of Mexico.title: Oil Seeps in the Gulf of Mexico
Oil Seeps in the Gulf of Mexico.caption_short: Oil slicks stood out in the glare of the Sun in May 2006 on the Gulf of Mexico.

Ice Storm Hits the United States.title: Ice Storm Hits the United States
Ice Storm Hits the United States.caption_short: On January 27, 2009, a winter storm coated a broad swath of the United States with ice and snow.

Ash Plume from Klyuchevskaya Volcano.title: Ash Plume from Klyuchevskaya Volcano
Ash Plume from Klyuchevskaya Volcano.caption_short: On January 27, 2009, the Klyuchevskaya Volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula released a continuous plume of ash and steam.

Dust Plume off Argentina.title: Dust Plume off Argentina
Dust Plume off Argentina.caption_short: Dust blew off the coast of Argentina in late January 2009.

Biokovo Range, Croatia.title: Biokovo Range, Croatia
Biokovo Range, Croatia.caption_short: The pitted appearance of the karst topography in Coatia’s Biokovo Range is highlighted by early morning sunlight in this astronaut photograph from December 29, 2008.

Ouargla Oasis, Algeria.title: Ouargla Oasis, Algeria
Ouargla Oasis, Algeria.caption_short: In the arid stretches of southern Algeria lies the Ouargla Oasis.  The imagery shows both urbanization near the oasis, and an assortment of irrigated fields in the region.

Antarctica.title: Antarctica
Antarctica.caption_short: Relatively few people have seen Antarctica. But now, the MODIS Rapid Response System is producing daily photo-like images of Antarctica.

Joshua Tree National Park, California.title: Joshua Tree National Park, California
Joshua Tree National Park, California.caption_short: Three topographic and climatic zones converge in California’s Joshua Tree National Park, enriching the park’s biodiversity. The diverse terrain is shown in this Landsat image from May 28, 2003.

Snow and Fog in Pacific Northwest.title: Snow and Fog in Pacific Northwest
Snow and Fog in Pacific Northwest.caption_short: Snow topped mountain peaks while low clouds filled valleys in the Pacific Northwest in January 2009.

Cyclone Dominic.title: Cyclone Dominic
Cyclone Dominic.caption_short: Cyclone Dominic approaches the coast of Western Australia on January 26, one day prior to landfall.

Sulfur Dioxide Emissions, Bulgaria.title: Sulfur Dioxide Emissions, Bulgaria
Sulfur Dioxide Emissions, Bulgaria.caption_short: This image shows measurements of sulfur dioxide in the air over one of the largest power plants in eastern Europe, the Maritsa Iztok Complex in Bulgaria, on January 12, 2009.

City of Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada.title: City of Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada
City of Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada.caption_short: In this astronaut photograph, winter snows outline the street grid of the Fort William part of Thunder Bay, while suburban parks appear as roughly rectangular areas of unbroken white snow.

Grand Coulee Dam.title: Grand Coulee Dam
Grand Coulee Dam.caption_short: This natural-color image shows Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River in Washington, as well as the large area of cropland irrigated by the reservoir upstream.

Continuing Activity at Chaiten Volcano.title: Continuing Activity at Chaiten Volcano
Continuing Activity at Chaiten Volcano.caption_short: In January 2009, an explosive dome collapse occurred at Chaitén Volcano, and ash and steam eruptions were visible from space.

Dust Plume off Egypt.title: Dust Plume off Egypt
Dust Plume off Egypt.caption_short: A dust plume several hundred kilometers long blew off the north coast of Egypt and over the Mediterranean Sea in late January 2009.

Antarctic Warming Trends.title: Antarctic Warming Trends
Antarctic Warming Trends.caption_short: For a long time, it seemed that Antarctica was immune to global warming. But a new analysis of satellite and weather station data has shown that Antarctica has warmed on average since 1957.

Inauguration Day Crowds in Washington, D.title: Inauguration Day Crowds in Washington, D.C.
Inauguration Day Crowds in Washington, D.caption_short: Despite the blustery weather, more than a million people gathered in Washington, D.C., on January 20, 2009, to witness and celebrate the inauguration of the forty-fourth president of the United States.

Cyclone Fanele.title: Cyclone Fanele
Cyclone Fanele.caption_short: Cyclone Fanele storm nearly fills the Mozambique Channel in this photo-like image from January 20, 2009.

Cyclones Fanele and Eric.title: Cyclones Fanele and Eric
Cyclones Fanele and Eric.caption_short: This image shows Tropical Cyclones Eric and Fanele near Madagascar on January 19, 2009.

2008 Global Temperature.title: 2008 Global Temperature
2008 Global Temperature.caption_short: Calendar year 2008 was the coolest year since 2000, but it was still in the top ten warmest years since the start of record-keeping in 1880. Most of Europe, Russia, and the Arctic were warmer than average, while much of the Pacific Ocean was cooler than usual.

Continued Activity at Chaiten Volcano.title: Continued Activity at Chaiten Volcano
Continued Activity at Chaiten Volcano.caption_short: Months after its violent eruption in May 2008, Chile’s Chaitén Volcano remained active, and continued to send lahars—avalanches of volcanic ash, water, and mud—into the town of the same name.

Haze Collects over Bangladesh.title: Haze Collects over Bangladesh
Haze Collects over Bangladesh.caption_short: Haze concentrated over Bangladesh on January 20, 2009, likely the result of urban and industrial pollution.

Mt. Marra, Sudan.title: Mt. Marra, Sudan
Mt. Marra, Sudan.caption_short: In western Sudan, lies a network of volcanic mountains and fertile valleys where just enough rain falls to sustain agriculture. This mountainous region contains a volcanic field known as Jebel Marra.

Sand Dunes, Marzuq Sand Sea, Southwest L.title: Sand Dunes, Marzuq Sand Sea, Southwest Libya
Sand Dunes, Marzuq Sand Sea, Southwest L.caption_short: This astronaut photograph shows classic large and small sand masses of the central Sahara Desert, where wind is a more powerful land-shaping agent than water.

Porcupine Gorge, Queensland, Australia.title: Porcupine Gorge, Queensland, Australia
Porcupine Gorge, Queensland, Australia.caption_short: Porcupine Gorge and other sandstone canyons carving through a basalt plateau create dramatic topography in central Queensland.

Poor Harvest in Kenya.title: Poor Harvest in Kenya
Poor Harvest in Kenya.caption_short: Ten million people could face hunger in Kenya after a poor harvest, Kenya’s government warned on January 9, 2009. According to the Associated Press, the government declared a state of emergency to free up funds for food aid.

6.1 Earthquake in Costa Rica.title: 6.1 Earthquake in Costa Rica
6.1 Earthquake in Costa Rica.caption_short: A 6.1 magnitude earthquake in Costa Rica shook the country on January 8, 2009.  The event triggered landslides which killed at least 20 people.

Landslide in Guatemala.title: Landslide in Guatemala
Landslide in Guatemala.caption_short: On January 4, 2009, a mountainside in northern Guatemala suddenly collapsed, sending thousands of tons of rock and debris downhill and burying a nearby road. The event occurred in the state of Alta Verapaz, some 200 kilometers (124 miles) north of Guatemala’s capital city.

Torrential Rains flood Australia.title: Torrential Rains flood Australia
Torrential Rains flood Australia.caption_short: During the first two weeks of January 2009, torrential rains brought both drought relief and severe flooding to parts of Queensland and Northern Territory in northern Australia.

CERES Global Cloud Fraction.title: CERES Global Cloud Fraction
CERES Global Cloud Fraction.caption_short: For more than 10 years, students from around the world have been participating with NASA in a science project called Students Cloud Observations Online, or S’COOL, for short.

Fires in Ghana.title: Fires in Ghana
Fires in Ghana.caption_short: This image of Ghana and its neighbors, Ivory Coast to the west and Togo to the east, shows widespread agricultural fires on January 11, 2009.

Raven Ridge, Colorado.title: Raven Ridge, Colorado
Raven Ridge, Colorado.caption_short: This astronaut photo of Raven Ridge, Colorado, shows a long stretch of exposed rocks that mark the K-T Boundary, the time when dinosaurs went extinct.

Mount Mabu, Mozambique.title: Mount Mabu, Mozambique
Mount Mabu, Mozambique.caption_short: In 2005, researchers at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew stumbled upon secret: a little-known forest in northern Mozambique.

Earthquake in Papua, Indonesia.title: Earthquake in Papua, Indonesia
Earthquake in Papua, Indonesia.caption_short: In the early morning hours of January 4, 2009, a pair of powerful earthquakes rattled Papua, Indonesia.

Changing Sea Ice along the Antarctic Pen.title: Changing Sea Ice along the Antarctic Peninsula
Changing Sea Ice along the Antarctic Pen.caption_short: Changing weather conditions left their mark on sea ice along the Antarctic Peninsula in late 2008 and early 2009. In mid-December 2008, melt water resting on the sea ice colored it sky blue. At the beginning of 2009, however, the sea ice appeared snowy white, and cracks had begun along the ice margin.

Earthquake Swarm in Yellowstone Park.title: Earthquake Swarm in Yellowstone Park
Earthquake Swarm in Yellowstone Park.caption_short: Between December 26, 2008, and January 6, 2009, several hundred small earthquakes rumbled beneath Yellowstone Lake in northern Wyoming.

Snow in Syria.title: Snow in Syria
Snow in Syria.caption_short: Snow covered much of Syria on the first day of 2009.

Floods in Sumatra, Indonesia.title: Floods in Sumatra, Indonesia
Floods in Sumatra, Indonesia.caption_short: Crops, roads, and homes were all swamped when rivers burst their banks in southern Sumatra in late December 2008.

Coal Ash Spill, Tennessee.title: Coal Ash Spill, Tennessee
Coal Ash Spill, Tennessee.caption_short: In the early morning hours of December 22, 2008, the earthen wall of a containment pond at Tennessee’s Kingston Fossil Plant gave way. The breach released 1.3 million cubic meters (1.7 cubic yards) of sludge, infiltrating a nearby river and damaging dozens of homes.

Plume from Soufriere Hills Volcano.title: Plume from Soufriere Hills Volcano
Plume from Soufriere Hills Volcano.caption_short: The Soufriere Hills volcano on the Caribbean island of Montserrat released a plume of ash and/or steam in late November 2008.

Dust Storm, Turkmenistan, Central Asia.title: Dust Storm, Turkmenistan, Central Asia
Dust Storm, Turkmenistan, Central Asia.caption_short: An astronaut photograph shot with a short focal length lens shows a wide swath of central Asia and the Earth’s limb in the distance.

Yellow River Delta, China.title: Yellow River Delta, China
Yellow River Delta, China.caption_short: China’s Yellow River, or Huang He, travels through soft plateaus of silt, picking up a massive sediment load on its journey. The sediment carried by the river has reshaped China’s coast, adding several hundred square kilometers of land.

Sediment off the Yucatan Peninsula.title: Sediment off the Yucatan Peninsula
Sediment off the Yucatan Peninsula.caption_short: A burst of color lit the shallow waters of the Gulf of Mexico off the Yucatan Peninsula on December 14, 2008.

Tagula Island, Louisiade Archipelago.title: Tagula Island, Louisiade Archipelago
Tagula Island, Louisiade Archipelago.caption_short: Scattered like turquoise and emeralds across the dark blue waters of the Coral and Solomon Seas, the coral reefs and forested islands of the Louisiade Archipelago stretch southeastward from the tip of Papua New Guinea for over 350 kilometers.

Mount St. Helens, October 2008.title: Mount St. Helens, October 2008
Mount St. Helens, October 2008.caption_short: Nearly three decades after the catastrophic eruption of Mount St. Helens, the impact on the forest in the blast zone is still obvious in this astronaut photograph. South of the mountain, lush green forests cover the landscape, while north of the mountain, vegetation remains sparse.

Global Fires.title: Global Fires
Global Fires.caption_short: Fire is ubiquitous, both a tool and a destructive force. Like plants, fire grows and wanes in seasons.

Plume from Koryaksky Volcano.title: Plume from Koryaksky Volcano
Plume from Koryaksky Volcano.caption_short: Koryaksky (or Koryakski) Volcano on Russia’s Kamchatka Peninsula released a plume of ash and/or steam in late December 2008.

Cyclone Billy.title: Cyclone Billy
Cyclone Billy.caption_short: On December 19, 2008, Tropical Cyclone Billy made landfall in Western Australia as a Category 2 storm.

Breckenridge and Copper Mountain Ski Slo.title: Breckenridge and Copper Mountain Ski Slopes, Colorado
Breckenridge and Copper Mountain Ski Slo.caption_short: Snow-covered ski runs at Copper Mountain and Breckenridge stand out from darker forests of the Tenmile Mountain Range in this astronaut image from October 24, 2008.

Manantali Reservoir, Mali.title: Manantali Reservoir, Mali
Manantali Reservoir, Mali.caption_short: The Bafing River travels through Guinea and Mali, and eventually joins with the Senegal River in western Africa. In the 1970s, drought struck the region, prompting a multinational effort to develop irrigation and power generation.

Low Clouds over Central China.title: Low Clouds over Central China
Low Clouds over Central China.caption_short: A temperature inversion most likely created this stunning view of low clouds hugging the contours of the Sichuan Basin in Central China in early December 2008.

Tibet.title: Tibet
Tibet.caption_short: Cloudless skies allowed a clear view of Tibet’s arid plains and numerous lakes in mid-December 2008.

Sea Turtle Beaches, Eastern St. Croix.title: Sea Turtle Beaches, Eastern St. Croix
Sea Turtle Beaches, Eastern St. Croix.caption_short: Important nesting grounds for leatherbacks, hawksbills, and green sea turtles are found on beaches in Jack, Isaac, and East End Bays, pictured in this astronaut photograph from March 29, 2005.

Dust Plumes from the Bodele Depression.title: Dust Plumes from the Bodele Depression
Dust Plumes from the Bodele Depression.caption_short: Dual dust plumes blew out of the Bodele Depression in late December 2008.

Volcanoes on Baja California Peninsula.title: Volcanoes on Baja California Peninsula
Volcanoes on Baja California Peninsula.caption_short: This natural-color image from the Landsat satellite on October 5, 2000, shows El Aguajito Caldera, Las Tres Vírgenes, and La Reforma Caldera on the Baja Peninsula.

Rare Snow Covers Portland.title: Rare Snow Covers Portland
Rare Snow Covers Portland.caption_short: An unusually heavy snow storm has blanketed the Willamette Valley in Oregon including the Portland metropolitan area.

Progressive Forest Clearing, Bolivia.title: Progressive Forest Clearing, Bolivia
Progressive Forest Clearing, Bolivia.caption_short: This photograph shows deforestation and agricultural development along Rio Parapet&iacute in Bolivia between 1995 and 2008.

Urban Heat Island: Baltimore, MD.title: Urban Heat Island: Baltimore, MD
Urban Heat Island: Baltimore, MD.caption_short: Maps of land surface type and temperature for Baltimore, Maryland, reveal the tight relationship between development and the urban heat island effect. Land temperatures in the densely developed city center are as much as 10 degrees Celsius higher than the surrounding forested landscape.

Insect Damage in British Columbia Forest.title: Insect Damage in British Columbia Forests
Insect Damage in British Columbia Forest.caption_short: As the size of British Columbia’s pine beetle infestation has grown, forest managers have begun to need a technique to identify damage over large areas. Relying on a variety of data sources, including satellite data, scientists from Goddard Space Flight Center conducted a survey of insect-damaged forests in British Columbia. This image shows their assessment of insect damage overlain on a topography map.

Pine Beetle Infestation in British Colum.title: Pine Beetle Infestation in British Columbia
Pine Beetle Infestation in British Colum.caption_short: Pine beetles and conifer forests have long coexisted in British Columbia. Numerous outbreaks of pine beetle infestations occurred throughout the twentieth century, but toward the end of the century, conditions were just right for an epidemic.

Beijing Restrictions Reduce Pollution.title: Beijing Restrictions Reduce Pollution
Beijing Restrictions Reduce Pollution.caption_short: Measures taken by Chinese officials to improve Beijing’s air quality during the 2008 summer Olympic games dramatically cut concentrations of two major pollutants, say NASA researchers.

Typhoon Dolphin.title: Typhoon Dolphin
Typhoon Dolphin.caption_short: This natural-color image of Typhoon Dolphin on December 16 shows the storm’s cloud-filled eye and a cluster of thunderstorms in the northeast quadrant.

Sermersuaq (Humboldt) Glacier, Greenland.title: Sermersuaq (Humboldt) Glacier, Greenland
Sermersuaq (Humboldt) Glacier, Greenland.caption_short: This pair of images shows the retreat of the Sermersuaq (Humboldt) Glacier in northwestern Greenland between 2000 and 2008. Sermersuaq Glacier is the widest tidewater glacier in the Northern Hemisphere.

New England Ice Storm.title: New England Ice Storm
New England Ice Storm.caption_short: A winter storm coated New England states with ice on December 11-12, 2008, cutting off power to more than a million people across New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Maine, Connecticut, and New York.

Plume from Chaiten Volcano.title: Plume from Chaiten Volcano
Plume from Chaiten Volcano.caption_short: Chile’s Chaitén Volcano remained active in mid-December 2008, releasing plumes of ash and/or steam

California Coast, Los Angeles to San Die.title: California Coast, Los Angeles to San Diego Bay
California Coast, Los Angeles to San Die.caption_short: This hand-held astronaut photo shows urban areas and fault-related topographic features from San Bernardino, California, to Tijuana, Mexico.

El&rsquo;gygytgyn Crater, Russian Far Ea.title: El’gygytgyn Crater, Russian Far East
El&rsquo;gygytgyn Crater, Russian Far Ea.caption_short: Russia’s Lake El’gygytgyn rests inside a 3.6-millon-year-old meteorite crater, and preserves the longest continuous climate record in the Arctic.

Rare Snow in the U.S. Deep South.title: Rare Snow in the U.S. Deep South
Rare Snow in the U.S. Deep South.caption_short: Several inches of wet snow fell across Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama in December 2008.

Haze over India and the Bay of Bengal.title: Haze over India and the Bay of Bengal
Haze over India and the Bay of Bengal.caption_short: Thick haze collected south of the Himalaya in early December 2008, spreading toward the south and east over the Bay of Bengal.

Chlorophyll in the Gulf of Tonkin.title: Chlorophyll in the Gulf of Tonkin
Chlorophyll in the Gulf of Tonkin.caption_short: A phytoplankton bloom colored the Gulf of Tonkin iridescent green in early December 2008.

Eruption on Soufriere Hills Volcano.title: Eruption on Soufriere Hills Volcano
Eruption on Soufriere Hills Volcano.caption_short: On December 2, 2008, an explosion occurred on the west side of the Soufriere Hills lava dome. Volcanic material flowed through the city of Plymouth, setting some buildings on fire.

Sidoarjo Mud Flow, Indonesia.title: Sidoarjo Mud Flow, Indonesia
Sidoarjo Mud Flow, Indonesia.caption_short: Despite its destructive history, the Sidoarjo mud flow in eastern Java, Indonesia, appeared contained by levees in November 2008.

2007 San Francisco Bay Oil Spill.title: 2007 San Francisco Bay Oil Spill
2007 San Francisco Bay Oil Spill.caption_short: Five days following an oil spill in San Francisco Bay on November 7, 2007, radar imagery showed oil slicks across broad areas of the bay as well in the open waters of the Pacific Ocean.

Deriba Caldera, Sudan.title: Deriba Caldera, Sudan
Deriba Caldera, Sudan.caption_short: In this astronaut photograph, a pair of jewel-toned lakes sit in the Deriba Caldera on top of  Mount Marra Volcano in western Sudan. Shadows throw the steep southern wall of the outer crater into sharp relief.

Sebkhat El Melah, Tunisia.title: Sebkhat El Melah, Tunisia
Sebkhat El Melah, Tunisia.caption_short: Along Tunisia’s southeastern coast is a flat plain of about 150 square kilometers (58 square miles) that lies below sea level. Known as Sebkhat El Melah (or Sebkha El Melah), it is in an evaporite basin.

Volcanic Haze over Hawai&rsquo;i.title: Volcanic Haze over Hawai’i
Volcanic Haze over Hawai&rsquo;i.caption_short: Volcanic gases from Kilauea, the most active volcano in Hawai'i, blanketed the islands in thick haze in early December 2008.

Sulfur Dioxide from Noril&rsquo;sk, Russ.title: Sulfur Dioxide from Noril’sk, Russia
Sulfur Dioxide from Noril&rsquo;sk, Russ.caption_short: Much of the world’s nickel, palladium, and copper comes from a single location in Siberia, the Noril’sk mining facility. Because the metals must be extracted from sulfide ore, however, the same facility also produces much of the world’s sulfur dioxide pollution.

Haze in the Vale of Kashmir.title: Haze in the Vale of Kashmir
Haze in the Vale of Kashmir.caption_short: In early December 2008, haze neatly filled the Vale of Kashmir, leaving skies clear over the surrounding snowcapped peaks.

New Cracks in the Wilkins Ice Shelf.title: New Cracks in the Wilkins Ice Shelf
New Cracks in the Wilkins Ice Shelf.caption_short: As Southern Hemisphere summer approached, radar imagery from the European Space Agency revealed new cracks were continuously forming in the seaward edge of the Antarctic Peninsula's Wilkins Ice Shelf.

First Winter Storm Slams Illinois.title: First Winter Storm Slams Illinois
First Winter Storm Slams Illinois.caption_short: Freshly fallen snow blanketed Chicago and the rest of northern Illinois on December 2, 2008.

Haze over the Yellow Sea.title: Haze over the Yellow Sea
Haze over the Yellow Sea.caption_short: A thick plume of haze blew off the coast of China, across the Yellow Sea, and toward the Korean Peninsula in early December 2008.

Alluvial Fan in Southern Iran.title: Alluvial Fan in Southern Iran
Alluvial Fan in Southern Iran.caption_short: A dry river channel carves through the Zagros Mountains in southern Iran and spreads out across the valley floor in a silvery fan. A broad belt of lush agricultural land follows the curve of the alluvial fan.

Cities of the Dead, Nile River Delta, Eg.title: Cities of the Dead, Nile River Delta, Egypt
Cities of the Dead, Nile River Delta, Eg.caption_short: This detailed astronaut photograph illustrates a portion of the Nile Delta that includes two royal cemeteries, Abusir and Saqqara-North.

Old Faithful.title: Old Faithful
Old Faithful.caption_short: Yellowstone National Park’s Old Faithful Geyser erupts so reliably—every hour on the hour—you can set your watch by it. So goes the legend, but it’s not true.

City Lights, 2003.title: City Lights, 2003
City Lights, 2003.caption_short: Observations collected at night shed light on the changing face of our planet.

Earth Viewed by Apollo 8.title: Earth Viewed by Apollo 8
Earth Viewed by Apollo 8.caption_short: This stunning photo came back to Earth with the Apollo 8 astronauts in late December 1968.

Floods in Santa Catarina, Brazil.title: Floods in Santa Catarina, Brazil
Floods in Santa Catarina, Brazil.caption_short: Several days of heavy rain caused widespread flooding in the southeastern Brazilian state of Santa Catarina at the end of November 2008.

Cyclone 06B over Sri Lanka and India.title: Cyclone 06B over Sri Lanka and India
Cyclone 06B over Sri Lanka and India.caption_short: Cyclone 06B was poised over northern Sri Lanka and southern India on November 26, 2008.

Northern Oman.title: Northern Oman
Northern Oman.caption_short: Much of Oman’s landscape is low-lying, hot, and dry. Northern Oman, however, contains rugged mountains, some of the highest elevations in eastern Arabia, and varied vegetation.

Vakhsh River and Lake Nurek, Tajikistan.title: Vakhsh River and Lake Nurek, Tajikistan
Vakhsh River and Lake Nurek, Tajikistan.caption_short: This false-color image shows the central part of the Vakhsh River, including the Nurek Dam and reservoir.

Great Divide, Rocky Mountains, Colorado.title: Great Divide, Rocky Mountains, Colorado
Great Divide, Rocky Mountains, Colorado.caption_short: This astronaut photograph highlights a portion of the Great Divide in the Rocky Mountains approximately 31 kilometers due west of Boulder, Colorado.

Barberton Mountains, South Africa.title: Barberton Mountains, South Africa
Barberton Mountains, South Africa.caption_short: The mountains around the town of Barberton, South Africa, are rich in both history and prehistory. Referred to as the Barberton Greenstone, these mountains derive their name from their greenish hue, and they comprise what may be the world’s best-known greenstone belt.

Flooding on the Nzoia River.title: Flooding on the Nzoia River
Flooding on the Nzoia River.caption_short: Like many rivers across the world, the Nzoia River in western Kenya pushes over its banks annually. In November 2008, the river burst through the dykes to flood the low-lying land around it.

Lee Clouds in Russia&rsquo;s Ural Mounta.title: Lee Clouds in Russia’s Ural Mountains
Lee Clouds in Russia&rsquo;s Ural Mounta.caption_short: This photo-like image paints a picture of the movement of air and weather over the Ural Mountains in southern Russia, with the western mountains covered with snow and the eastern plain dry. The image also illustrates the influence of the mountains on cloud formations.

Locusts in Australia.title: Locusts in Australia
Locusts in Australia.caption_short: In November 2008, the Australian Plague Locust Commission reported that a few small swarms of locusts had started to develop in New South Wales.

Plankton Bloom Surrounds Chatham Islands.title: Plankton Bloom Surrounds Chatham Islands
Plankton Bloom Surrounds Chatham Islands.caption_short: On November 15, 2008, a bloom of plant-like organisms known as phytoplankton encircled the Chatham Islands.

Floods in Ethiopia.title: Floods in Ethiopia
Floods in Ethiopia.caption_short: Heavy rains starting on November 2 pushed several rivers in southeastern Ethiopia over their banks.

Lava Flow from Erta Ale Range, Ethiopia.title: Lava Flow from Erta Ale Range, Ethiopia
Lava Flow from Erta Ale Range, Ethiopia.caption_short: In early November 2008, a volcano erupted in the Erta Ale Range in northeastern Ethiopia, producing a fresh lava flow.

Haze Along the Himalaya.title: Haze Along the Himalaya
Haze Along the Himalaya.caption_short: Haze lingered along the southern face of the Himalaya in early November 2008, continuing a pattern from the previous month.

Hell&rsquo;s Half Acre Lava Field, Idaho.title: Hell’s Half Acre Lava Field, Idaho
Hell&rsquo;s Half Acre Lava Field, Idaho.caption_short: The Hell’s Half Acre Lava Field is the youngest and easternmost lava flow associated with the Snake River Plain basalts.

Cheju Island, South Korea.title: Cheju Island, South Korea
Cheju Island, South Korea.caption_short: Cheju Island is an oval-shaped volcanic landmass off the southern tip of the Korean Peninsula. The island’s dominant feature is Halla Mountain, a volcano that has been dormant since the early eleventh century.

Earthrise 1966.title: Earthrise 1966
Earthrise 1966.caption_short: Long before man journeyed to the moon and looked back at the tiny, fragile planet that houses humanity, lunar orbiters were sending back pictures of home.

Deforestation in Mato Grosso, Brazil.title: Deforestation in Mato Grosso, Brazil
Deforestation in Mato Grosso, Brazil.caption_short: The most conspicuous difference between the images is the widespread forest clearing—visible as rectangles of gray-beige—that had occurred by 2006.

L&rsquo;Anse Aux Meadows, Canada.title: L’Anse Aux Meadows, Canada
L&rsquo;Anse Aux Meadows, Canada.caption_short: At the northern tip of the island of Newfoundland are the archeological remains of the oldest known European settlement in the New World, L'Anse aux Meadows.

New Sunspot Cycle Begins.title: New Sunspot Cycle Begins
New Sunspot Cycle Begins.caption_short: After a slow start, a pair of sunspots in late 2008 signaled an upswing in Solar Cycle 24.

Fall Colors the Caucasus Mountains.title: Fall Colors the Caucasus Mountains
Fall Colors the Caucasus Mountains.caption_short: Fall color highlights the rugged topography of the Caucasus Mountain Ranges and surrounding lowlands on November 9, 2008.

Hurricane Paloma.title: Hurricane Paloma
Hurricane Paloma.caption_short: A late-season storm, Paloma developed as a tropical depression in the Caribbean off the coast of Honduras and Nicaragua on November 5, 2008. This image shows the storm as a Category 1 hurricane on November 6.

Arkenu Craters, Libya.title: Arkenu Craters, Libya
Arkenu Craters, Libya.caption_short: The Arkenu Craters in northern Africa are one of only a few pairs of double impact structures identified on Earth.

Tripoli, Libya.title: Tripoli, Libya
Tripoli, Libya.caption_short: Deserts cover Libya’s interior, but cities such as Tripoli have expanded along the fertile lowlands of the country’s coast.

Adis Abeba, Ethiopia.title: Adis Abeba, Ethiopia
Adis Abeba, Ethiopia.caption_short: Although it is only the tenth largest country in Africa, Ethiopia is the second most populous country on the continent. Nearly a third of the country’s urban population lives in Adis Abeba (more commonly known as Addis Ababa).

Activity on the Erta Ale Range.title: Activity on the Erta Ale Range
Activity on the Erta Ale Range.caption_short: In early November 2008, a volcano erupted in the Erta Ale Range in northeastern Ethiopia.

Correcting Ocean Cooling.title: Correcting Ocean Cooling
Correcting Ocean Cooling.caption_short: When scientists corrected errors in ocean temperature data, a mysterious cooling trend that appeared to occur between 2003 and 2005 disappeared.

Drought in Eastern Ethiopia.title: Drought in Eastern Ethiopia
Drought in Eastern Ethiopia.caption_short: Poor rains were forecast for eastern Ethiopia at the end of 2008.

Fires in Northwest India.title: Fires in Northwest India
Fires in Northwest India.caption_short: Scores of agricultural fires burned in the northwest Indian states of Punjab and Haryana on November 3, 2008.

Floods in Eastern France.title: Floods in Eastern France
Floods in Eastern France.caption_short: Intense rain swelled rivers in east-central France on November 2 and November 3, 2008, forcing hundreds of evacuations and closing two major highways.

Heavy Rain in Vietnam.title: Heavy Rain in Vietnam
Heavy Rain in Vietnam.caption_short: Torrential rains brought the worst floods in decades to northern and central Vietnam in early November 2008.

Pueblo Chemical Depot, Colorado.title: Pueblo Chemical Depot, Colorado
Pueblo Chemical Depot, Colorado.caption_short: This astronaut photograph illustrates the unusual man-made landscape of the Pueblo Chemical Depot located near the city of Pueblo, Colorado.

Sidi Toui National Park, Tunisia.title: Sidi Toui National Park, Tunisia
Sidi Toui National Park, Tunisia.caption_short: Sidi Toui National Park is in the southern half of Tunisia, in a relatively mountainous area close to the Libyan border.

Fires Increase Surface Ozone.title: Fires Increase Surface Ozone
Fires Increase Surface Ozone.caption_short: Wildfires can raise ground-level ozone concentrations to unhealthy levels even at large distances from the fire location.

Flooding in Central America.title: Flooding in Central America
Flooding in Central America.caption_short: Tropical Depression 16 moved ashore over Honduras on October 16 and slowly cut its way over Central America, dumping heavy rain from southeastern Mexico to Costa Rica.

Flooding in Yemen.title: Flooding in Yemen
Flooding in Yemen.caption_short: Widespread flooding swept over eastern Yemen after Tropical Storm Three drenched the country with heavy rains on October 24-25, 2008.

6.4 Magnitude Earthquake Near Quetta, Pa.title: 6.4 Magnitude Earthquake Near Quetta, Pakistan
6.4 Magnitude Earthquake Near Quetta, Pa.caption_short: Pakistan is prone to earthquakes because it lies in the collision zone of the India tectonic plate to the south and the Eurasian plate to the north. A magnitude 6.4 earthquake hit the rural, mountainous region of southwestern Pakistan on October 29, 2008.

Tropical Storm Rashmi.title: Tropical Storm Rashmi
Tropical Storm Rashmi.caption_short: Tropical Storm Rashmi came ashore over Bangladesh on October 27, 2008, taking at least 15 lives, reported Reuters.

Melt Ponds, Northeastern Greenland.title: Melt Ponds, Northeastern Greenland
Melt Ponds, Northeastern Greenland.caption_short: To understand ice sheets, glaciologists venture both below the surface with ice cores, and into the sky with satellites. Satellite imagery of the Greenland Ice Sheet reveals melt ponds that can affect glacier flow and sea level.

Assateague and Chincoteague Islands, Vir.title: Assateague and Chincoteague Islands, Virginia
Assateague and Chincoteague Islands, Vir.caption_short: This photo-like image of Chincoteague Island and the southern section of Assateague was acquired by the IKONOS satellite on June 27, 2001.

Desert Erosion, A Modern Libyan Landscap.title: Desert Erosion, A Modern Libyan Landscape
Desert Erosion, A Modern Libyan Landscap.caption_short: This detailed astronaut photograph shows the classic patterns of an eroded desert landscape, about 300 kilometers (190 miles) south of Libyaâ€™s Mediterranean coast.

Jwaneng Diamond Mine, Botswana.title: Jwaneng Diamond Mine, Botswana
Jwaneng Diamond Mine, Botswana.caption_short: otswana ranks first among the worldâ€™s gem-quality diamond producers, and diamond mining makes up 70 percent of the nationâ€™s export revenue. The Jwaneng Diamond Mine, in south-central Botswana, sits atop the convergence of three kimberlite pipesâ€”diamond-rich geologic formations. Because the pipes meet just below the surface and cover some 520,000 square meters (128.5 acres) at ground level, the diamonds are mined from an open pit rather than a mine tunneled below the surface.

The Ozone Hole of 2008.title: The Ozone Hole of 2008
The Ozone Hole of 2008.caption_short: On September 12, 2008, the Antarctic ozone hole reached its maximum size for the year.

Tropical Storm Three, Gulf of Aden.title: Tropical Storm Three, Gulf of Aden
Tropical Storm Three, Gulf of Aden.caption_short: The third tropical cyclone of the season in the northern Indian Ocean brought rare rains to the desert regions of Yemen and Oman in the third week of October 2008 after the storm hooked around the Horn of Africa and entered the Gulf of Aden.

Coronado Island and the Gulf of Californ.title: Coronado Island and the Gulf of California, Mexico
Coronado Island and the Gulf of Californ.caption_short: Located in the Bahia de los Angeles, Isla Coronado sits in the Gulf of California, just off the eastern shoreline of Mexico’s Baja Peninsula. The island is approximately 7 kilometers long, and it is dominated by Volcan Coronado on the northern end.

Fall Color in the U.S. Northeast.title: Fall Color in the U.S. Northeast
Fall Color in the U.S. Northeast.caption_short: Fall was beginning to color the East Coast of the United States when MODIS captured this image on October 12, 2008.

Hurricane Omar.title: Hurricane Omar
Hurricane Omar.caption_short: In this image, the storm more than covers the expanse of ocean between the northern coasts of Colombia and Venezuela, and Puerto Rico.

Seasonal Changes in Global Net Radiation.title: Seasonal Changes in Global Net Radiation

Dust Over the western Sahara Desert.title: Dust Over the western Sahara Desert

Fires near Los Angeles, California.title: Fires near Los Angeles, California
Fires near Los Angeles, California.caption_short: Driven by powerful Santa Ana winds, wildfires raged near Los Angeles, California, in mid-October 2008.

Sirmilik National Park, Canada.title: Sirmilik National Park, Canada
Sirmilik National Park, Canada.caption_short: To the Inukitut-speaking peoples of the Canadian Arctic, northern Baffin Island is Sirmilik, “the place of the glaciers.” When Canada established the area as a National Park in 2001, they gave it the same name.

Hurricane Norbert.title: Hurricane Norbert
Hurricane Norbert.caption_short: In the afternoon of October 8, 2008, Hurricane Norbert grew to a Category 4 hurricane.

Sandy Cape, Fraser Island, Australia.title: Sandy Cape, Fraser Island, Australia
Sandy Cape, Fraser Island, Australia.caption_short: Fraser Island, the world’s largest sand island, is located along the coastline of Queensland, Australia, and it includes Great Sandy National Park. The island was designated a World Heritage site in 1992, in part due to its outstanding preservation of geological processes related to sand dune formation.

Forest Changes in British Columbia.title: Forest Changes in British Columbia
Forest Changes in British Columbia.caption_short: In British Columbia’s Coast Mountains, some 200 kilometers (125 miles) inland from the Pacific Ocean, rivers and lakes cut tortuous paths through rugged terrain. The peaks and valleys in this region are covered with forest, but the forest has changed over the years due to human use and insect pests, in particular, the mountain pine beetle.

Snake River Plain, Idaho.title: Snake River Plain, Idaho
Snake River Plain, Idaho.caption_short: Though its name might suggest something formed by the meandering of an ancient river, the Snake River Plain of southern Idaho had a far more violent birth. Scars from its relatively recent geologic origin are printed on its surface.

Floods on the Mexican Gulf Coast.title: Floods on the Mexican Gulf Coast

Blood Falls, Antarctica&rsquo;s Dry Vall.title: Blood Falls, Antarctica’s Dry Valleys
Blood Falls, Antarctica&rsquo;s Dry Vall.caption_short: Among the most interesting—and most puzzling—features of the Dry Valleys lakes is the reddish stain seeping out of Taylor Glacier into Lake Bonney. The reddish discoloration, known as Blood Falls, appears in this false-color image.

Bouvet Island, South Atlantic Ocean.title: Bouvet Island, South Atlantic Ocean
Bouvet Island, South Atlantic Ocean.caption_short: Bouvet Island is known as the most remote island in the world; Antarctica, over 1600 kilometers (994 miles) to the south, is the nearest land mass. Located near the junction between the South American, African, and Antarctic tectonic plates, the island is mostly formed from a shield volcano—a broad, gently sloping cone formed by thin, fluid lavas—that is almost entirely covered by glaciers.

Bou Craa, Western Sahara.title: Bou Craa, Western Sahara
Bou Craa, Western Sahara.caption_short: Phosphate deposits are one of Western Sahara’s few natural resources. At the Bou Craa phosphate mine, 100 kilometers (about 60 miles) from the coastal city of El Aaiún, abundant, pure phosphate deposits lie near the surface.

Wetland Damage Along the Gulf Coast.title: Wetland Damage Along the Gulf Coast
Wetland Damage Along the Gulf Coast.caption_short: This photo-like image of the Texas and Louisiana coasts shows the impact of Hurricane Ike’s powerful storm surge on coastal wetlands. Hurricane Ike came ashore bringing with it a wall of water that stretched from Galveston, Texas, across all of coastal Louisiana.

Tropical Storm Mekkhala.title: Tropical Storm Mekkhala
Tropical Storm Mekkhala.caption_short: Within days after Typhoon Hagupit drenched northern Vietnam with flood-inducing rains, Tropical Storm Mekkhala moved ashore on September 30, 2008.

Lights of Las Vegas.title: Lights of Las Vegas
Lights of Las Vegas.caption_short: This image of nighttime lights in the southwestern outskirts of Las Vegas, Nevada, was one of several images that an international team of scientists analyzed in 2007.

Flooding from Hurricane Ike in Texas.title: Flooding from Hurricane Ike in Texas
Flooding from Hurricane Ike in Texas.caption_short: Hurricane Ike came ashore along the U.S. Gulf Coast on September 13, 2008, and the storm’s eye narrowly missed Galveston and Houston. Although the storm produced tremendous damage in both cities, perhaps the greatest damage was caused by the storm surge, which inundated the coastline near Galveston. The storm surge was greatest east of Galveston, reaching 4.6 meters (15 feet) above sea level. The area devastated by the storm surge includes coastline immediately east of Galveston Bay.

Fall Colors Across Alaska.title: Fall Colors Across Alaska
Fall Colors Across Alaska.caption_short: The colors of Alaska are those of a landscape captured between summer and fall. The northern slopes of the Brooks Range Mountains and the Arctic Coastal Plain are not yet dusted with snow, but the vegetation has the burnished look of autumn. The gray, bare rock of the mountain is exposed at high altitudes, while valleys and lower slopes are lined with green.

Tifernine Dune Field, Algeria.title: Tifernine Dune Field, Algeria
Tifernine Dune Field, Algeria.caption_short: The Tifernine Dune Field is located at the southernmost tip of the Grand Erg Oriental, a “dune sea” that occupies a large portion of the Sahara Desert in eastern Algeria.

Huge Bushfire in the Kalahari.title: Huge Bushfire in the Kalahari
Huge Bushfire in the Kalahari.caption_short: Beginning in late August 2008, fire broke out near the western border of Botswana’s Central Kalahari Game Reserve. By late September, some 40,000 square kilometers (about 15,500 square miles) had burned, scorching roughly 80 percent of the park, according to news reports.

Flooding in Gonaives, Haiti.title: Flooding in Gonaives, Haiti
Flooding in Gonaives, Haiti.caption_short: In September 2004, more than 2,500 people died when Tropical Storm Jeanne unleashed torrential rain on northeastern Haiti, triggering devastating floods and mudslides in Gonaïves. The disaster was repeated in September 2008, when a string of storms—Gustav, Hanna, and Ike—drenched Haiti.

Arctic Sea Ice Reaches Annual Minimum.title: Arctic Sea Ice Reaches Annual Minimum
Arctic Sea Ice Reaches Annual Minimum.caption_short: The arrival of Northern Hemisphere autumn signals the end of the seasonal retreat of Arctic sea ice. Polar scientists from the National Snow and Ice Data Center report that sea ice appeared to hit its lowest extent on September 14, 2008, when the area at least 15 percent covered by ice dropped to 4.52 million square kilometers (1.74 million square miles).

Tunis, Tunisia.title: Tunis, Tunisia
Tunis, Tunisia.caption_short: The urban area of Tunis is located on a flat coastal plain, and is distinguished in this astronaut photograph from the surrounding desert by the pattern of grey and tan buildings and the dark street grid. The city is bordered by an evaporating saline lake to the northeast known as Sebkhet Arina (upper left).

Klondike Gold Rush National Historical P.title: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park, Alaska

Hurricane Ike Impact on High Island, Tex.title: Hurricane Ike Impact on High Island, Texas
Hurricane Ike Impact on High Island, Tex.caption_short: East of Galveston, Texas, a thin barrier beach—Bolivar Peninsula—stretches along the coastline. On the far eastern end of Bolivar Peninsula is High Island, so named for the salt dome that boosts the area some 11.6 meters (38 feet) above the rest of the Gulf Coast. After Hurricane Ike passed, rescuers combed through the destroyed communities along Bolivar Peninsula. Thanks to its elevation, High Island fared better than other parts of the Peninsula.

Fires in Oregon and Northern California.title: Fires in Oregon and Northern California

Hurricane Damage on the Bolivar Peninsul.title: Hurricane Damage on the Bolivar Peninsula

Penny Ice Cap in 1979 and 2000.title: Penny Ice Cap in 1979 and 2000
Penny Ice Cap in 1979 and 2000.caption_short: Penny Ice Cap is the southernmost of Canada’s big ice caps. Like other glaciers and ice caps in the Northern Hemisphere, the Penny has been thinning and its valley glaciers have been retreating in recent decades.

Island of Ischia, Italy.title: Island of Ischia, Italy
Island of Ischia, Italy.caption_short: he island of Ischia is approximately 30 kilometers southwest of Naples, Italy, in the western Bay of Naples (part of the Tyrrenhian Sea). While the island’s rocks are volcanic in origin, much of the island’s geology and current topography is characterized by blocks of uplifted rock and sunken areas between weak spots or cracks in Earth’s crust.

Crack in the Petermann Glacier.title: Crack in the Petermann Glacier
Crack in the Petermann Glacier.caption_short: The Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) on NASA’s Terra satellite captured this image of the rift on the Petermann Glacier on September 7, 2008. The rift, which appeared by 2001, is filled with thin ice and covered with snow.

Fires in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, and South.title: Fires in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, and South Africa

Retreat of Serson Ice Shelf.title: Retreat of Serson Ice Shelf
Retreat of Serson Ice Shelf.caption_short: This trio of images from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Terra satellite shows the rapid break up of the Serson Ice Shelf between July 28 and July 31.

Dust Plumes over the Middle East.title: Dust Plumes over the Middle East
Dust Plumes over the Middle East.caption_short: On September 10, 2008, dust plumes blew over Iraq and neighboring countries.

Hurricane Ike Weakens over Cuba.title: Hurricane Ike Weakens over Cuba
Hurricane Ike Weakens over Cuba.caption_short: As Hurricane Ike battered Cuba on September 8, 2008, the rugged island punched back. Rainfall rates dropped dramatically as the storm crossed the island, losing power from a Category 4 to Category 2 hurricane.

Both Routes Around Arctic Open at Summer.title: Both Routes Around Arctic Open at Summer’s End

The Brahmaputra River floods Northeast I.title: The Brahmaputra River floods Northeast India

Sunglint on the Amazon River, Brazil.title: Sunglint on the Amazon River, Brazil
Sunglint on the Amazon River, Brazil.caption_short: The setting sun glints off the Amazon River and numerous lakes in its floodplain in this astronaut photograph from August 19, 2008. Large areas of sunglint are common in oblique views. Sunglint images reveal great detail in surface water—in this case the marked difference between the smooth outline of the Amazon and the jagged shoreline of the Uatumã River.

Ningaloo National Marine Park, Western A.title: Ningaloo National Marine Park, Western Australia
Ningaloo National Marine Park, Western A.caption_short: Ningaloo Reef, along the shore of Western Australia, is Australia’s largest fringing coral reef. It is also the world’s only large reef located so close to a landmass.

Floods Cover Bihar, India.title: Floods Cover Bihar, India
Floods Cover Bihar, India.caption_short: Standing on the ground, it is impossible to gauge the full scope of a disaster the size of the Kosi River floods in northeastern India. On August 18, 2008, the river, swollen with monsoon rains, burst through an embankment into an old channel. By September 2, the river’s course still took it over populated land that had not been prone to flooding in the past. To grasp the full extent of this flood, you need the view from space.

Ice Shelves Retreat on Ellesmere Island.title: Ice Shelves Retreat on Ellesmere Island
Ice Shelves Retreat on Ellesmere Island.caption_short: Between July and August 2008, the Serson and Ward Hunt Ice Shelves lost ice, and the Markham Ice Shelf disintegrated completely.

Fires in Mozambique and South Africa.title: Fires in Mozambique and South Africa
Fires in Mozambique and South Africa.caption_short: A river of smoke several hundred kilometers wide flowed off the southeast coast of Africa in early September 2008. The smoke was coming from hundreds, probably thousands, of fires burning in Mozambique, South Africa, and Swaziland.

Storm-Churned waters off Cuba.title: Storm-Churned waters off Cuba
Storm-Churned waters off Cuba.caption_short: Gustav may have spared the United States from the destruction that many feared, but it hit Cuba hard.

Aeolian Islands.title: Aeolian Islands
Aeolian Islands.caption_short: The Aeolian Islands formed from a chain of volcanoes in the Tyrrhenian Sea north of the island of Sicily. Geologists and volcanologists have studied the islands since the eighteenth century, and the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) declared them a World Heritage Site in 2000 because of their value to the study of volcanic processes.

Mt. Gambier, South Australia.title: Mt. Gambier, South Australia
Mt. Gambier, South Australia.caption_short: Sitting near Australia’s rugged southern coast, the South Australian town of Mount Gambier is built on the side of an extinct volcano. The caldera of the volcano has filled with rainwater, forming a very deep lake that provides the town with water. The large caldera lake is called Blue Lake due to a rather peculiar characteristic: the water turns a brilliant cobalt blue during the summer and early fall.

Wrangel Island, Russia.title: Wrangel Island, Russia
Wrangel Island, Russia.caption_short: The ghostly white shapes northeast and immediately southwest of Wrangel Island are sea ice. Over the course of the satellite record, Arctic sea ice has advanced and retreated past Wrangel Island many times. From 1979 to 2000, the sea ice edge at the end of summer generally fell somewhere in the vicinity of Wrangel Island, but this is not the first summer when the sea ice edge has retreated well north of the island.

Dust near Cyprus.title: Dust near Cyprus
Dust near Cyprus.caption_short: The dust that blew toward Cyprus from the coast of Turkey on the previous day stretched and thinned on August 26, 2008.

Aral Sea, 2000-2008.title: Aral Sea, 2000-2008
Aral Sea, 2000-2008.caption_short: A Soviet-era plan to turn the arid plains of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan into fertile cropland resulted in the near-total diversion of the water that once fed the Aral Sea.
